contents.Text: RhythmiRust started as 2 bash scripts: one for downloading, one for searching.
Of course, this became hard to manage and use, so I decided that I should probably combine them
into a single application that also works cross-platform.
I wanted to make a [[[strong:music player]]] due to the lack of one that offered a search feature, let alone a downloader.
My primary aim was to make an effortless method for downloading/syncing videos from platforms like YouTube, Spotify, and SoundCloud;
these downloaded files would then be stored locally for preservation and playback.
RhythmiRust was intended to be an efficient, portable, feature-rich and lightweight application.
This means minimal CPU and RAM usage, and a fully portable cross-platform configuration
with album art support and metadata editing.

contents.Header2: The Influence of Music on RhythmiRust's Development

contents.Text: As a music enthusiast with a vast collection of 19,709 songs,
I desired an easy method to search through and play them, and download/sync new additions.

contents.Header2: The Core Values Guiding the Development of RhythmiRust

contents.Text: RhythmiRust should maintain a consistent GUI appearance.
No elements should appear outside of the GUI (such as opening system file dialogue).
The application should be self-contained, requiring minimal external dependencies.
RhythmiRust has only three external dependencies: two for network/download functionality and another for converting formats and image processing.
